text.p: China's Shenzhen Development Bank Ltd's board of directors have formally appointed Zhou Lin as the bank's new president, the company said on Wednesday.
The announcement comes one month after securities regulators dismissed He Yun, former president of the bank, over the bank's illegal trading of its own shares.
Authorities also confiscated illicit profits of 90.34 million yuan from the trading, and barred He from the financial sector for five years.
Zhou was previously the president of the Shenzhen branch of the Guangdong Development Bank said the company statement, which was published in the Shenzhen-based Securities Times.
On Wednesday, shareholders of the Shenzhen-listed domestic currency A share company approved a five-for-10 bonus issue plus a pre-tax cash payout of 0.2 yuan per share as a dividend for 1996.
Investors had feared the bank would change the dividend plan, which was drafted before the stock scandal, due to the cash seizure.
Shenzhen Development Bank is considered the leader of Shenzhen's A share market in light of its large capitalisation and strong earnings record.
Trading in the bank's A shares was suspended on Tuesday and Wednesday morning and would resume on Wednesday afternoon, the Shenzhen Stock Exchange has said.
The bank's move to leave the dividend plan intact helped boost the Shenzhen A share market in early trading on Wednesday morning, brokers said.
